How to
The most important thing first. Your task is to solve equations for their unknown X! Thoughtfully summarize and shift elements to solve each one.
It\'s a breeze to summarize elements. Just mark an element with your fingertip and draw an arrow to your target.
Marking several elements is also easily done. Keep your fingertip on one element and you will mark more and more!
Naturally, this works with your target too.

Fractions, for example, are summarized exactly like that. Stay with your fingertip on the first fraction until it\'s marked. After that, draw an arrow to the second. Finally, wait a bit without lifting your fingertip.
Shifting elements is no sorcery too. Mark one or more with your fingertip and draw a line to the other side of the equation, done!
Last but not least the game\'s control bar. Its job is to assist you while you are solving the equations.
This symbol will undo your last action.
Plus-minus multiplies both sides of an equation with minus one. This is especially useful when you solved one for -X.
Don\'t worry if you can\'t solve an equation, simply click here to get the next one.
Useful information about your actions are hidden behind the little \'i\'.
If you\'re done playing, you can click here to exit the game.
Good job solving lots of equations so far! I hope you had fun and learned a thing or two. x=1 is lovingly built to show that math is fun when taught right.
Honest reviews help a lot to improve x=1. So if you have a minute, click the button below to review x=1. Just a rating is, of course, appreciated too!
Equation
The most important element of an equation (besides you trying to solve it!) is its equal sign. It symbolizes the balance between both sides.
It gets interesting once an unknown X sneaks into it! Now it\'s important to find the correct number to retain the balance.

This is even useful apart from math lessons! Think about preparing a gaming session (of course you want to play x=1) with your pal. You definitely need enough food to munch. Your pal eats 2 pizzas in an hour and you eat 1 in the meantime. How many pizzas do you have to order to prepare for a 3 hour session?
You can take on this problem with an equation! Just find the X and this overwhelmingly important problem is solved!
Order of operations
Multiplication and division always take precedence over addition and subtraction. It\'s the most important rule when solving an equation! Let\'s neglect the rule for once and see what happens:
This can\'t be right! The equation is off balance! Now stick to the rule and multiply before adding.
This yields the correct result. It\'s not possible to calculate without the rule. Remember it well!
Addition
The addition is the first and most simple mathematical operation. There are still some important rules, you need to remember. First of all adding 0 doesn\'t change the result:
Secondly, it\'s possible to interchange parts of an addition, as long as you don\'t forget about the signs.
Adding two fractions is just a little bit more complicated, since both have to have the same denominator.

If the denominators are different, you have to extend both fractions to make sure the denominators match. To do so, you first have to multiply both denominators. Afterwards you extend the numerators by multiplying the numerator of the first fraction with the denominator of the second and vice versa. At last, just add the two extended numerators.
Subtraction
The subtraction is the inverse of the addition. You can reverse an addition with it:
Now let\'s see how you can retrieve one addend from the result. That\'s an easy task with the subtraction - just subtract the 2 from the 3!
The rules for the subtraction are similar to those of the addition. Likewise subtracting 0 doesn\'t change the result.
Moreover, it\'s possible to interchange parts of a subtraction, as long as you don\'t forget about the signs.
Subtracting two fractions is also slightly more complicated, but don\'t worry, you can do it! Again, both have to have the same denominator.

If the denominators are different, you have to extend both fractions to make sure the denominators match. To do so, you first have to multiply both denominators. Afterwards you extend the numerators by multiplying the numerator of the first fraction with the denominator of the second and vice versa. At last, just subtract the two extended numerators.
Multiplication

The multiplication is an abbreviation of the addition. That\'s the only thing you need to know! Just look at the long addition on the left side and compare it to its abbreviation on the right. What a wonderful way to save space!
Subsequently multiplying by 0 has to result in 0.
As it\'s basically an addition, you\'re allowed to interchange the parts of a multiplication too. Don\'t forget the signs, though.
Let\'s have a closer look at the signs. Be careful of how many elements with a negative sign you multiply. A single negative sign will get you a negative result.
And what happens with two negative signs? Well, minus * minus results in a plus!
Finally the multiplication of fractions. Just multiply their numerators and denominators, easy!
Division
The division is the inverse of the multiplication. You can reverse a multiplication with it! Take a look at this little example:
If you want to know how many \'2s\' are hidden inside the result, a division will answer your question!
Which leads to the most important rule. Never ever divide through 0! You would get infinity as result and you can\'t calculate with infinity!
Finally, let\'s talk about compound fractions. You only have to remember one thing: The compound fraction is just a multiplication of the numerator with the reciprocal of the denominator.
Reciprocal seems awfully complicated at first, but have a look at this.
The fraction on the right is simply the inverse of the left. Just reverse the fraction for its reciprocal.
Reducing
Reducing is a wonderful way to simplify fractions. You just have to divide the numerator and denominator through their greatest common factor! Take a look at this example:
The greatest common factor is 2. So scratch the 2 from the numerator and divide the denominator through it afterwards. Easy, effective, and your result is a simplified fraction.
But caution! You can only reduce if the numerator and denominator are either a product or a single element - you can\'t reduce additions and subtractions.
The X is just a variable and likes to stay flexible! Thus, you can\'t summarize these elements of the equation. Try to skillfully release the X instead and you\'re one step closer to the result!
Never divide through 0 - the result would be infinity! You\'ll understand once you divide through very small numbers. Start with one-hundredth.
Continue with one one-thousandth.
And then one ten-thousandth.
The result is increased every time you divide through a smaller number. Infinity is reached once you divide through 0. But infinity isn\'t a number - you can\'t calculate with it!
Reducing only makes sense if the numerator and denominator are either a product or a single element. You notice it immediately if you reduce the 2 in the following fraction.
To do so, you have to divide the whole numerator and denominator through 2 - and don\'t forget the 3! That\'s only possible if you separate the fraction into two parts.
Now you reduce the first fraction and your result will be 1. But wait a second, what happened to the other one? You have to add it again and there you\'re back at the beginning!
Be careful to simplify the equation with every step. Go for the complicated expressions first - that\'s the fastest way!
DONATE
x=1 is my passion project and I have tremendous fun working on it! Hopefully you have fun too, and even learned a thing or two.
I like to keep x=1 free and without advertisement to allow everyone to enjoy math. This is why I want to humbly ask you for help.
A small donation once or every now and then is enough to avoid costs and advertisement. I can\'t offer you much beyond this knowledge, though.
Donate %1$s

FEEDBACK

'The subject of mathematics is so serious that nobody should miss an opportunity to make it a little bit entertaining.'
Blaise Pascal

That's what I want to achieve with x=1. Since one opinion (mine!) is surely not enough for this matter: Did you enjoy x=1? And, very importantly, what can I improve? Feel free to contact me via Email or Twitter!

Email: xgleich1@gmail.com
Twitter: https://twitter.com/xgleich1
